studyMetadata.title: Study of 3D visualizations for sustainable design
studyMetadata.description: Study of 3D visualizations for sustainable design.
organizations: Department of Mechanichal and Production Engineering, Aarhus University

uiConfig.studyEndMsg:
Thank you for completing this study!
Please download the results file when prompted and send it to either teodor.vernica@mpe.au.dk or devr@mpe.au.dk with the title '3D LCA Survey Results'.

response.prompt: What data did you use to complete the task? (select all that apply)
What was the most useful data for accomplishing this task?

Consent to Participate in Research Study


Title of the research project: Evaluation of 3D visualizations for sustainable design
Purpose of the Study:
You are invited to participate in a research study conducted by Teodor Vernica at Aarhus University. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of 3D Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) visualizations in various sustainable product design tasks.
What will you do in the study?
Participants will complete three tasks that simulate different aspects of the product design process while incorporating sustainability metrics. The tasks will involve using a 3D visualization tool developed by the researcher.
Data Collection:
No personal data such as names, organization affiliations, age, or other identifying information will be collected during this study.
Voluntary Participation:
Your participation in this study is entirely voluntary. You may withdraw from the study at any time without any consequences.
Confidentiality:
All data collected will be kept confidential and used solely for the purpose of this research. Since no personal data is collected, there is no risk of identifying participants.
Publication of Results:
The results of this survey may be published in academic journals, conference proceedings, or other scientific publications. However, since no personal data is collected, individual participants will not be identifiable in any publications.
Contact Information:
If you have any questions about the study, please contact Teodor Vernica, PhD Student, teodor.vernica@mpe.au.dk or Devarajan Ramanujan, Associate Professor, devr@mpe.au.dk.
Consent:
By participating in this study, you acknowledge that you have read and understood the information provided above and agree to participate in the research.

response.prompt: How often do you consider the environmental impact of manufacturing when designing a product? (in addition to cost, functional performance, durability, etc.)
How interested are you in incorporating sustainability into your design process?
In your opinion, what are the main barriers preventing you from considering sustainability in your designs more often? (select all that apply)

options.label: Poor integration of LCA and CAD tools
Considering environmental impact adds additional complexity to the design process
Lack of regulatory or organizational requirements
High costs associated with implementing sustainability measures
Time constraints in the design process
Limited access to reliable environmental data
Lack of support from management or stakeholders
Insufficient training or education on sustainability practices
Complexity of using LCA tools and interpreting results
Low market demand for sustainable products
Technological limitations in current design tools
Uncertainty about the benefits of sustainable design
None. I am already considering sustainability in my designs often
None. I am not interested in considering sustainability in my designs more often

response.prompt: Type 'ready' once you are done exploring the study interface and 3D LCA visualization.
What is the geometric feature with the highest environmental impact contribution to Shaft Design A?
What is the main cause for the high impact of the identified geometric feature?

options.label: The chosen material, including primary production
Multiple processing steps required to manufacture the feature
High environmental impact of one or two required processing steps

response.prompt: If other cause, please specify:
What is the second highest contributing geometric feature for Shaft Design A?
What is the main cause for the impact of the second highest geometric feature of the component?

options.label: The chosen material, including primary production
Multiple processing steps required to manufacture the feature
High environmental impact of one or two required processing steps

response.prompt: If other cause, please specify:

Considering the FEA results and expected loading conditions, what geometric change to Shaft Design A would you explore to achieve the highest reduction in environmental impact, without significantly affecting its stress performance?
Please give a brief motivation for your choice.
What geometric features would change as a result of your proposed geometric change? (select all that apply)
If other, please specify below:
How do you anticipate the change to affect Shaft Design A's sustainability and stress performance?

options.label: Decrease in CO2 emissions and peak stress
Decrease in CO2 emissions but slight increase in peak stress
Decrease in CO2 emissions but significant increase in peak stress
